You are an expert in causal inference. The following question is not a typical commonsense query, but rather a meticulously designed question created by a professor specializing in causal inference, intended to assess the students' mastery of the course content.
Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: CEO has a direct effect on director and manager. Manager has a direct effect on employee. Director has a direct effect on employee. For managers who don't sign termination letters and directors who don't sign termination letters, the probability of employee being fired is 9%. For managers who don't sign termination letters and directors who sign termination letters, the probability of employee being fired is 47%. For managers who sign termination letters and directors who don't sign termination letters, the probability of employee being fired is 50%. For managers who sign termination letters and directors who sign termination letters, the probability of employee being fired is 85%. For managers who don't sign termination letters, the probability of director signing the termination letter is 66%. For managers who sign termination letters, the probability of director signing the termination letter is 73%. For managers who sign termination letters, would it be less likely to see employee being fired if the manager had signed the termination letter?
Start your answer with 'Yes' or 'No', followed by additional reasoning or evidence to support your explanation.
action.label: context

action.content:
No
The probability of the manager having signed the termination letter is 73%. The probability of the director having signed the termination letter is 73%. The probability of the manager having not signed the termination letter is 27%. The probability of the director having not signed the termination letter is 27%. The probability of the employee being fired when the manager has not signed the termination letter and the director has not signed the termination letter is 9%. The probability of the employee being fired when the manager has not signed the termination letter and the director has signed the termination letter is 47%. The probability of the employee being fired when the manager has signed the termination letter and the director has not signed the termination letter is 50%. The probability of the employee being fired when the manager has signed the termination letter and the director has signed the termination letter is 85%. The probability of the manager having signed the termination letter and the director having not signed the termination letter is 73%*27%=1.971%.
